ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was a combination of recorded lecture and live discussion
Recorded lecture combined with live virtual lectures
Breakout rooms with other students
Live + recorded lecture
Recorded lectures with in-person discussion during class time
Recorded lecture.
The course consisted of live virtual classes and recorded lectures.
Recorded lectures combined with mandatory in-class discussions
recorded lecture
Bi-weekly synchronous class session
Recorded videos
Flipped classroom, recorded lecture (which is usual for Prof. Faison and not an innovation given COVID) and in-class discussion over Zoom, usually with peers in breakout rooms.
Both recorded lectures and class time dedicated to group work and time for questions to further understand lecture topics.
Recorded lectures and live discussions (flipped class)
Recorded lecture with discussion section where we did practice problems together.
Virtual live discussions in small groups
This was a "flipped" course, consisting of recorded lectures to be watched on our own time, and live "discussion" of said lectures during the class' scheduled meeting time.
Pre-recorded lectures and virtual class mainly discussing questions and practice problems.
Reversed classroom.
Recorded lectures with live virtual full-class meetings, characterised by frequent smaller breakout rooms.
Recorded lectures, class lectures, discussion sections.
Recorded lecture followed by synchronous full-class discussions.
Both recorded lectures and live and virtual discussion sections/lecture classes with professor and the entire class (though attendance wasnt mandatory)
Recorded lecture with in-person weekly discussion.

recorded lecture
live virtual discussion.
Recorded lectures to be watched before scheduled class time. During class time a non-recorded discussion mainly led by the professor over the material discussed.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have a much better understanding of the things in our solar system and an idea of what they look like and how they got there.
I learned a lot of critical thinking skills from this course because the answers to the questions require reading between the lines.
Survey about planets and stars
I gained a basic knowledge of astronomical concepts, ranging from orbits and light physics to the life cycles of planets and stars. I also worked on my math skills and scientific reasoning.
Introduction to astronomy
I have a much firmer grasp on the formation of stars and planets, as well as some hope for life outside planet earth.
Astronomy and basic astrophysics

How astronomers estimate distances to planets/stars, solve for intrinsic properties of planets/stars (e.g. mass, power output, orbital velocity), and identify the presence of planets or moons when they aren't visible. Some basic information about planets in our solar system (e.g. chemical compositions and theorized evolutionary history).

I had taken the Galaxies and the Universe class but this really helped me understand the smaller scale stuff better and also was helpful in understanding how we know the things we know about planets, stars and our galaxy.

I learned many basic computational and conceptual skills and insights for astronomy. I feel comfortable with many techniques of gathering inforamtion about planets and stars and understanding how they are born, live, and die.
As the title of the course says I learned basic astronomy. you also learn about quantitative, critical thinking skills, and how scientists think.
I gained a deeper insight into the universe around me and acquired the skills to measure the properties of stars and planets.
Basic knowledge of astronomy.
Astronomy and different areas of it.
I had never taken an astronomy course prior to ASTRO 110, so I definitely developed a really strong core understanding of the basics of astronomy.
I learned about how we've arrived at our current understanding of the universe and how we might make new discoveries in the near future.
I learned many things about plants and stars.
This course helps give a deeper insight into the world of astronomy and the basics used in this field.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The TFs were the biggest strength. They were all so incredibly helpful and really helped me understand the course a lot better than I would have without them. They were also incredibly accessible and very willing to help. I felt like the live discussions were a waste of my time because they just felt disorganized and disconnected from the class somehow. I felt like I didn't really gain anything from the live discussion. I also felt like sometimes the lectures were not explained in a way that was helpful for the problem set, so I really relied on the TFs to fill the gaps in my knowledge.
It wasnt entirely clear what the primary things we should focus on were, concerning each topic. Also, going into break out rooms with random people every class didnt help facilitate collaboration.
This course was very informative, but the calculations were not clear. I mostly found myself using the book and internet sources to figure out how to do the assignments.
Strength: not too difficult for a 5th class Weakness: Live lecture is useless as you learn nothing related to the psets

Strengths: The material is interesting and Professor Faison is a good teacher
Weaknesses: The in-class discussion was not particularly engaging

I think the content material is interesting and presented with just enough specificity  however, I think the format of having pre-recorded lectures and then only doing practice problems in class often left me a bit confused about the course material. I think that offering a quick review in class of the presented lecture concepts would be helpful.

Strengths: The professor was very engaged and there were a lot of resources available to use
Weaknesses: The in-class discussions felt rushed, and sometimes when no one in the class knew the answer to a discussion question the professor would not provide the answer

Weaknesses- The final and midterm were incredibly more difficult than anything done in PSETs or discussed in class. 
Strengths- The discussion sections and recorded lectures were easy to follow and assisted immensely with PSETS.
Math skills and knowledge of space

The class material is very interesting and I would say easy to follow if you really take in everything - going to lecture, office hours, discussion sections, and readings. I did sometimes find myself stuck on the PSETs without going to office hours and I wish the answers to the practice problems In the class were posted somewhere cause It would've been another resource to make the class easier.

Strengths: recorded lectures allowed me to absorb the knowledge as slowly as I wanted

Weaknesses: live group discussions with classmates did not help me learn the information

I personally found the flipped classroom format less helpful than one might expect.  In-class discussion was often somewhat lifeless and unhelpful, and it often amounted to the sensation that we had two lectures per class meeting instead.
It was generally interesting but lectures could get long and boring. Also, PSETS were not graded promptly. TAs were helpful.
The course took a lot of time during the week to do all problem sets and a strength was that sections were optional.
There were many times during the course where the pace felt a bit too fast for an introductory courseand the virtual format intensified this issue.
Course is comprehensive, though slightly more challenging than its description boasts. Previous math and science knowledge is immensely useful.

Strengths: the design of the curriculum. In planning PSETs and class discussions, Prof. Faison did an excellent job thinking up interesting questions that drew on the lecture material but additionally (1) required creative thinking and (2) were relevant to current and/or historical astronomical discoveries. This helped make the material feel alive. 

Weaknesses: time management. I found that class discussions often focused heavily on relatively rudimentary material and shortchanged the more challenging questions. In the future, I'd recommend that Prof. Faison limit the time devoted to introductory matters -- star of the day, announcements, etc -- and instead concentrate on reviewing the trickier questions included in the discussion document.
This was one of the best courses that I have taken at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think online office hours are incredible, they make everything SO much more accessible. I think that there could've been a bit more structure in the live discussions.

The online lecture was effective, but the breakout rooms could be improved because some people did not use them properly. However, the breakout rooms encouraged student interaction, which helped if there was confusion from the lecture.
I didn't think that answering discussion questions in breakout rooms was a particularly good learning experience -- it was often awkward and sometimes people didn't really speak up.

I think the breakout rooms were utilized well in order to facilitate discussion during the pandemic. The virtual lectures were generally effective but widely varied in length, and a more consistent length would have helped me plan my time.
Recorded lectures were engaging

I think this course was already structured in a way that was not too difficult to pivot to being completely virtual. I think the recorded lectures were most helpful to understanding the material and they lost nothing while we were not in person.

The teacher's efforts to get everyone to participate succeeded, but virtual discussions were often filled with classmates who didn't participate. Coming together as a class virtually after small group discussions allowed for virtual engagement.
Everything succeeded.

While I appreciated the intention behind having frequent breakout rooms during class meetings, I actually found these to be quite anxiety-inducing. Having to work together on math problems under a time crunch with people Id never met before was often stressful, but this is very much a matter of personal preference and not objective criticism.

I enjoyed the course's usage of break-out groups to foster discussion and collaborative problem-solving. 

While there were in-person observing sessions, I would have loved if there had been more opportunities in that same vein available to remote students.
Having the lectures to watch before meeting for class was helpful. Class time was used to reinforce what we learned on our own.
The recorded lectures were great and allowed students to rewatch them when necessary for problem sets or studying for tests.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're not a science or a QR person and you need to take a class for credit, this class is worth it.
I would definitely recommend if it had been in-person, but over zoom, I think the course just becomes frustrating.
I would not recommend this course for someone, like myself, who has not taken a physics course. Otherwise, the class was very informative and opens your eyes to the wonders of the cosmos.
If you take this with the online format only I wouldnt take it. Live lecture felt like a waste of time.
Yes, it was an interesting class and a good way to fulfill one of my science distribution requirements. The weekly psets could get a bit tedious, though.

I would recommend it as a good way to brush up on math and science skills for non-majors, because the course material is very interesting and that is how it was useful to me. However, I definitely found myself confused at certain points in the semester with the content, and wished that there could have been a deeper dive into certain concepts beyond basic summary that would have made them make more sense.

100% recommend. You can't go wrong with Planets and Stars. Dr. Faison is super interesting and easy-to-follow. Manageable workload, good grading, and great survey of astronomy topics. If you've ever looked up in the sky and wondered about the Moon, planets, or distant stars, you'll really enjoy this class.
The problem sets and exams can be a little difficult, and the class definitely demands engagement and work to do well in it.
I would recommend this class for non-stem major students and those just looking to learn more about space exploration.

Yes! This course is amazing. Professor Faison and the TFs are all very helpful. As a non-STEM major, I felt that the workload was bearable and the content was extremely engaging. Even though it's an intro-level astronomy course, you learn a LOT about stars and our solar system. The material covered is absolutely fascinating.
Yes great course

I would indeed recommend, although ASTR 120 "Galaxies and the Universe" was a more interesting class. The information is helpful but not overly complex, and the mathematics required is just challenging enough to brush up on some helpful basics but not too difficult. PSets took me between four and eight hours, but they're graded leniently and with an eye toward understanding concepts, not flawless computation.
Yeah I really enjoyed it
Yes I would recommend this course. I found it very interesting and worth the commitment.

All I would say is proceed with caution that this class is a "gut" I really do think in order to get an A you do have to put in a small amount of effort and time showing up to everything. But other than that this class was a good option to fulfill the Science/QR credit for those who aren't STEM majors
Yes! I loved the teacher and the coursework is manageable compared to more strenuous QR and science classes.
Yes only if you like astronomy.

Students looking to receive a detailed but accessible introduction to astronomy should definitely take this course, though I dont know if its the best option for someone who is merely looking to complete a distributional requirement and who isnt actually interested in the subject matter.
I would only recommend this course to a student interested in astronomy as a field of study, perhaps a career or major.

Yes. If you're looking for a STEM credit that won't overburden you, this is a good way to go. The workload is reasonable, the presentation of the material is accessible, and you'll get to think creatively about how we know what we know about the universe.
Yes. This is an amazing course for anyone who likes space. The instructor is very good and is passionate about the topic.
Yes. This course is great for students needing a QR or Sc credit. However, it is not a gut especially if you have not taken any physics.
